items.title: Residents, 1st responders enter devastated Syrian city Aleppo after days of deadly fighting
items.summary_auto: Residents started returning to a contested neighbourhood in Syria's northern city of Aleppo on Sunday after days of deadly clashes between government forces and Kurdish-led forces. First responders entered to tend to residents, clear rubble and disarm mines.

items.title: Trump says no more Venezuelan oil or money to go to Cuba, pushes for deal
items.summary_auto: U.S. President Donald Trump on Sunday said no more Venezuelan oil or money will go to Cuba and suggested the communist-run island should strike a deal with Washington, ramping up pressure on the longtime U.S. nemesis.

items.title: N.S. artist helps kelp grow in homemade clay pots in underwater art installation
items.summary_auto: The pots were created using a mix of wild and commercial clay, and were placed in the waters of Cranberry Cove in December.

items.title: Rory Linkletter runs under 1 hour to break Canadian half marathon record for 2nd time in 4 years
items.summary_auto: Rory Linkletter is the first Canadian to run a half marathon under one hour, achieving the feat on a cool Sunday morning in Houston with a 59-minute 49-second clocking to beat former record holder Cam Levins by 69 seconds.

items.title: How 2 generations of Syilx Okanagan women reclaimed identity with language and QR codes
items.summary_auto: Last year, Syilx Okanagan woman Llana Teichroeb and her daughter Kim Kosick pronounced a number of campus street names in the Nsyilxcn language and linked them to QR codes that people can scan.

items.title: More than 1,000 Kyiv apartment blocks still without heat after Russian strike
items.summary_auto: More than 1,000 apartment buildings in the Ukrainian capital Kyiv are still without heat following a  devastating Russian attack  earlier this week, local authorities said on Sunday.

items.title: Central Alberta farmers amazed to welcome triplet calves for 2nd year in a row
items.summary_auto: Lucky 7 Cattle Co., near Sedgewick, Alta., started 2026 with a bang, welcoming a set of healthy triplet calves — for the second year in a row.

items.title: Gogolev inches closer to Olympic spot with first Canadian figure skating title
Illegal drugs advertised on social media; more airline competition taking off: CBC Marketplace cheat sheet
items.summary_auto: The CBC's Marketplace rounds up the consumer and health news you need from the week.

items.title: How a 1st year resident in St John's helped solve a medical mystery, and didn't stop there
items.summary_auto: Ian Gillies Jr. had spent a month in hospital, slowly getting sicker and sicker. Just as doctors warned the family he might not make it through the night, a "saviour arrived," says his dad.

items.title: The NDP leadership race is a nail-biter. But is anyone paying attention?
Appetite for a bargain: Rising food costs fuel boom in discount grocery stores
items.summary_auto: With the cost of living soaring, Ron Robinson is determined to save wherever he can — starting with his grocery bill. It’s why he shops at an ultra discount grocery chain in Montreal, where prices can be as much as 50 per cent less than a regular grocery store.

items.title: The apprenticeship of Prince George
items.summary_auto: When Prince William took his son, Prince George, to help at a homeless shelter recently, he was continuing George’s cautious but deliberate introduction to the public side of his royal life ahead while also offering a reminder of the influence William's mother, Diana, had on his own upbringing.

items.title: Carney hopes to 'recalibrate' once-frosty Canada-China relations with visit: PM's parliamentary aide
Carney wants to 'recalibrate' Canada-China relations with visit: PM's parliamentary aide
items.summary_auto: As the prime minister gears up to visit China next week, his parliamentary secretary, MP Kody Blois, says Mark Carney would like to "recalibrate" Canada's once-frosty relationship with the Chinese government and look at economic opportunities for the two nations.

items.title: U.S. attack in Venezuela creates risk, opportunity for guerrilla groups
items.summary_auto: The U.S. attack on Venezuela has shifted the ground for the various guerrilla groups operating across the borderlands with Colombia, raising fears of possible betrayal by Venezuelan regime officials, while opening the door to a wider conflict should U.S. boots ever hit the ground, local security experts say.
